channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: An XML representation of a search request

item.title: [AVRO-797] Built-in support for "any" types
item.description:
In my application, I generate an Avro protocol programmatically based on a model. While my model permits me to include things of type java.util.Object or java.lang.Enum, Avro only supports these notions via the concept of unions.

Therefore, to support this functionality, I iterate over my list of schemas and create a union of every type (or every enum type) in the protocol (and the null schema) to create my "any type" schema. This would be sufficient except that this new schema doesn't exist when I create the schemas in my model that would use it, so I need to put in a bogus placeholder schema, and this creates the added complexity of needing to programatically reconstruct my schemas, which is risky and problematic at best.

What I propose to address this is a new type of schema that acts as a layer of indirection and is not resolved during protocol generation (so no schema reconstruction is necessary).

Use Case #1: Translate generic "object" from model into Avro Schema

Field field = new Field("payload", Schema.createAny(), null, null); // default - any named type
List<Field> fields = new ArrayList<Field>();
fields.add(field);
Schema record = Schema.createRecord("Foo", null, "com.acme", false);
record.setFields(fields);

Use Case #2: Translate generic "enum" from model into Avro Schema

Field field = new Field("payload", Schema.createAny(Type.ENUM), null, null); // specifies a placeholder only for enums
List<Field> fields = new ArrayList<Field>();
fields.add(field);
Schema record = Schema.createRecord("Foo", null, "com.acme", false);
record.setFields(fields);

The consumer of the protocol should treat an "any" type schema as the union of every named type in the protocol, constrained by the specified Schema type.

If there is sufficient interest, I would be willing to provide a Java patch for this functionality.

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

item.title: [AVRO-798] add checksums to Snappy codec
item.description: A checksum might be included with each compressed block to better detect errors. While some filesystems (e.g. HDFS) may checksum data, not all do. Data files may also accumulate errors when copied between filesystems. For back-compatibility, we cannot easily add checksums to existing data files, but a new codec provides us with the opportunity to do this.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Here's a patch that implements this.
Patch that also updates spec.

Should we use PureJavaCRC32? Its a lot faster, though less so for larger arrays.

http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/hadoop/common/trunk/src/java/org/apache/hadoop/util/PureJavaCrc32.java?revision=953881&view=markup

We can just copy that code into a class in o.a.a.util.

At this point I'm more concerned about getting the format right than optimizing performance. If folks agree that CRC32 is a good checksum algorithm, that this computes & stores it correctly, and that storing it at the end of snappy blocks is appropriate, then we might commit this as-is now, so long as it's not horribly slow, and fine-tune performance later. Make sense?

Is it correct to cast the long returned from CRC32 to an int? That's the biggest concern I currently have about this patch...
Any objections to committing this?
I committed this.

item.title: [AVRO-799] Java: make text file tools accept codec
item.description: The text file tools should accept a codec name.
item.summary: Java: make text file tools accept codec

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
The attached patch:

  • adds '--codec' as an option to the 'fromtext' command;
  • improves the processing of text input to be both more efficient and better handle binary data on lines (anything except \r and \n)
  • adds tests for the text commands
  • fixes a few typos and bugs in the text commands
I committed this.

item.title: [AVRO-800] plot performance over time
item.description: It might be useful to have a nightly repository of Avro performance statistics, so that we can plot performance changes over time.

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

comments.comment: Here's a quick hack I whipped up. This could be run from a crontab with, e.g., daily, weekly and monthly graphs posted somewhere publicly.
One line change that produces anti-aliased lines.

I like it.

Does Apache provide a service for running this on consistent hardware?

We probably want to up the 'cycles' count of the test from 800 to 4000 or so to lower the variance if this is automated. 800 is a good level for manual tests without getting impatient – but regularly bounces around a bit. CYCLES is currently hard-coded, but we can make it a command line parameter that defaults to 800.
It might also be useful to have two charts to make it less noisy. One for reading and one for writing (-noread or -nowrite command line params).

There are two ways we might run this at Apache that I can think of:

  • Configure a nightly Jenkins build, where the image files are generated as artifacts. We seem to have some Jenkins builds, but they're not currently working.
  • Get a BSD Jail for Avro (http://www.apache.org/dev/freebsd-jails.html).

I'll first look into getting Jenkins working.

My hack above is really fragile. If someone adds a new test in the middle of Perf.java or otherwise changes its output then the graph will break. It would be better to move some of the logic into Perf.java. It might produce a file named <date>.json containing a record for each test run, e.g.:

{"name": "ReadInt", "mbps":357}
{"name": "WriteInt", "mbps":298}

Then we could write something that takes a directory of these files and produces the TSV file to plot, e.g.:

Date     ReadInt       WriteInt
20110414 357           298
...

This would leave blanks in columns where some files contain a test that others do not. It could also invoke gnuplot to produce the .png image from the TSV file.

item.title: [AVRO-801] Byte limit on Sasl RPC calls
item.description:
SaslSocketServer RPC will lock when sending more than 49149 byte on a single call, in 1.4.1 and 1.5.0

PoC for 1.5.0 attached
item.summary: Byte limit on Sasl RPC calls

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Here's a patch that fixes this, including a unit test.
Here's an improved patch. I'll commit this soon unless there are objections.
One more minor improvement...
I committed this.

item.title: [AVRO-802] Java: add documentation & test for map-only job w/ non-Avro input
item.description: The Java MapReduce API documentation should describe how to run a map-only job with non-Avro input and Avro output. Also, a test case should be added for this case.
item.summary: Java: add documentation & test for map-only job w/ non-Avro input

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Here's a patch that implements this.
I will commit this soon.
I committed this.
